data.text: Bicycle Touring Food: Bread, Bananas, Honey, and Peanut Butter

Does this seem to you to be an adequate selection of food to take along and munch on during a five hour, approximately fifty to sixty km early morning to late morning ride in an environment of high temperature (85 degrees plus), and high humidity (70 percent plus)? Your knowledge, feedback and input is highly appreciated.
I‚Äôd make up the pb&j sandwiches and ditch the jars and knife
data.author: Karen Robyn

data.text: You are not wanting lots of bulk in your gut on warm rides. Yes, all the nanas but a couple halved bagels with a bit of PB. Proper electrolyte replacement is key. Reload with bulk after you effort! Enjoy!
data.author: Tom Fanning

data.text: why is averyone banging on about electrolytes. I‚Äôm a long distance cyclist and never had an issue and I‚Äôm 65, ridden in all conditions.
data.author: Michele Visser-Fitton

data.text: I have to have electrolytes in the desert when the temps are over 90. It is so dry. It does not take much to end up in the hospital when not hydrated properly speaking from experience you can indeed die.
data.author: Jan Long

data.text: Indeed, in extreme conditions it important to remain hydrated but I see here that so many talk about electrolytes for what sounds like normal conditions. As I mentioned extreme conditions are another story.
data.author: Michele Visser-Fitton

data.text: you‚Äôre lucky. I‚Äôm 63 and I would need electrolytes on a ride like that assuming I‚Äôm pushing the pace a bit. Otherwise I get nasty cramps.
data.author: Rob Leacock

data.text: I‚Äôm 65 and just completed a 70km ride without electrolytes - just water and wholesome food. Now lying in my tent planning tomorrow‚Äôs route and listening to birdsong.
data.author: Michele Visser-Fitton

data.text: Well if I ride 5 hours in 85 degree Temps on water alone there will be no birdsongs to listen to at the ER!
data.author: Tom Fanning

data.text: electrolytes can be as little as a pinch of salt in your water. It depends on the water source as well, some water will already have plenty. At home I tend to add baking soda (sodium bicarbonate) and epsom salts (magnesium sulphate) but it can be just a pinch of regular table salt. It depends as well on the temperature, the level of effort, your own body, whether you get cramps, I have done plenty of riding just on plain water. But adding salt can be a good idea, it can improve hydration. You can also get electrolyte tabs or use mixes that include both electrolytes and carbs, I used use these racing. Another good cheap option in many countries is Oral Rehydration Salts, these are very inexpensive in many developing countries and are designed for optimum rehydration. Works great for cholera or cycling!
data.author: Ivan McAvinchey

data.text: Thank for the practical tips. Happily to date I seem to manage okay on regular water and occasionally carbonated mineral water or a cola or a 0%beer.
data.author: Michele Visser-Fitton

data.text: üòÇüòÇüòÇ
data.author: Michele Visser-Fitton

data.text: Too much bread. Water, bananas if you have to do those, eat the pb with a spoon.
data.author: Michael Manning

data.text: How many people?
data.author: Philip Bennie

data.text: i can do rides like that fasted on an empty stomach. just water
data.author: Christian Ramos

data.text: That looks like way too much to me. You don‚Äôt need all that for such a short ride. I see GI upset in your future if you consume much of that.
data.author: Joshua Lawton

data.text: Id take 2 peanut butter and banana sandwiches and spare bananas for later.
data.author: Steven Massheder

data.text: 2 bananas would be plenty, with enough water/electrolytes. As others have said though. I would normally do that fasted with just sugar free juice.
data.author: Jon Blanchard

data.text: In my case, I‚Äôd take maybe two bananas and a little roll of bread (because I can‚Äôt say no to bread), and I think I‚Äôll be fine :) Because of the humidity and hot weather, I would probably want to swap a banana for something juicier‚Ä¶like an orange! Oranges are my best snack on the road :) Enjoy your trip and don‚Äôt worry too much! Maybe there will be a little store on the way? :)
data.author: Lauriane Pdp

data.text: Probably too much for that. Switch out the bagel for a tortilla and only have that for breakfast maybe. Electrolytes in your water and go for some chips/nuts/date type things for along the way if you need a snack.
data.author: Andy Lovell

data.text: All you need for five hour is a good breakfast two water bottle and two chocolate bars the key is eating good the day before stocking up on carbs
data.author: John Smith

data.text: true if he goes in z2 z3 max. If he goes above, then not
data.author: Christian Eckert

data.text: Take some electrolytes, and make sure you know where you can get water. For food i take a big bag of haribo (or other small candy) and a bag of dates. Little and often is the best. I usually have a few gels and a carb drink mix, for emergencies.
data.author: Sam Sharpe

data.text: sugar - bad stuff!
data.author: Michele Visser-Fitton

data.text: Do you have anything positive to add? The problem with the cycling world is there too many condescending old men who rather than be positive and support new comers to the hobby have to try and belittle people.
data.author: Sam Sharpe

data.text: I am an absolute ambassador for cycling for so many (good) reasons, was converted many years ago. Today cycled a fabulous 70kms and now lie listening to the birdsong in my tent. I have nothing good to say about crap fuel for our bodies though‚Ä¶there you have it!
data.author: Michele Visser-Fitton

data.text: Seems a lot but everyone is different, I‚Äôd focus on calories from fluids like Tailwind Nutrition
data.author: Ben Houldsworth

data.text: 150-200 calories per hour replacement is plenty
data.author: Linda R. Davrath

data.text:
For me, this would be a lot more than enough food for a ride like that, especially if I ate a good breakfast before setting out. To each there own, though, and snacks are fun :). If you want to get math-y about it, there are calorie calculators that can help you estimate calories burned by different rides. Hope you have a good ride! https://keisan.casio.com/exec/system/1350958587
Bicycling Calorie Calculator
keisan.casio.com

data.text: seems adequate to do the ride several times

data.text: After all those carbs, I'd have to sleep under a tree for a few hours. Have a massive bowl of pasta the night before and do the ride on fruit and coffee.
data.author: Matthew Adams

data.text: I would eat a good breakfast of oats and berries before my ride, then take lots of water and an electrolyte drink or two for the ride. Eat nuts and bananas mid ride then have a nice lunch with hydrating foods afterward.

data.text: I‚Äôd say that‚Äôs perfect but those delicious buns may get squished, can‚Äôt go wrong with peanut butter!

data.text: Are you stopping to feed everyone you meet along the way? üòÇ Two bananas and a one sandwich will be more than enough. Have fun what ever you take!

data.text: At a guess i‚Äôd say thats way more than you‚Äôd need - but why not bring it all this time, and then guage what you might need for your next mission based on what you eat/don‚Äôt Everyone needs/wants to eat and drink different amounts - whatever works for you is whats most important

data.text: I guess it depends on the person, but a lot of folks would do a ride like that between breakfast and lunch, with maybe a couple bananas or power bars. With that weather, the most important thing will be water, and maybe electrolytes. Eat a good meal beforehand, snack a couple times in the middle, drink some gatorade.

data.text: Eat a small meal before you start and bring an apple and a banana and some peanut butter

data.text: Are you trying to gain weight on the ride?

data.text: Hello Cliff. I am just interested in being a healthier and happier cyclist.
data.author: John C Kimbrough

data.text: , I figured that. Sorry, I could not resist. In my opinion, that‚Äôs a lot of food for that distance. For that ride, I‚Äôd eat breakfast, carry as much water as I can with hopes of getting more on the ride. I‚Äôd probably take a 2 or 3 energy bars. On longer rides, I try to stop and eat at a restaurant. After a few rides, you will know what you need. Hydration is most important.
data.author: Cliff Multanen

data.text: Hello Cliff. I agree with your insights and advice. Thank you Cliff.

data.text: Well for comparison, I just rode 95km ( 50% off road ) and I consumed 1.5 litres of water, and one packet of Lidl's hungry hippos ( a pack of sweets ) So I would say you've too much ! Unless you're going to walk it üö∂‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è. . . . .

data.text: I think for me, just a few bananas one one bread would suffice. Plenty of water though.

data.text: Yes. I understand Ryan. Thank you for your response.
data.author: John C Kimbrough

data.text: Definitely too much. White bread to begin with is rubbish. Take a good, healthy multigrain brown bread sandwich, a piece of fruit and water. We cycled 60km last Sunday and ate a sandwich on the way, drank water and along the way had a coffee and small fruit cake. It was plenty. At the end of the ride a beer and some nuts!!
data.author: Michele Visser-Fitton

data.text: Great advice Michele. Thank you very much.
data.author: John C Kimbrough

data.text: P.S. a good wholegrain wholesome bread gives more energy at a slower rate and you will feel satisfied longer!

data.text: Yes. I understand.

data.text: I think its hardly depending on your fittness and the amount of uphills. What I miss is plenty of water.

data.text: Eat half of that two hours before the ride. Then eat a part of it every hour. Rule nr. 1: always start with filled tank. Rule nr. 2: fill every hour. Rule nr3: go slow but steady without big rests. Learn about your personal fueling strategy and needs on every ride

data.text: A helpful and in depth response Christian. Thank you very much.

data.text: Bananas create excessive mucous but work great and are cheap. I'd lose the bread and replace with potatoes and butter. Of all the riding food I have experimented with, potatoes are king. They are quickly bioavailable and easy to digest

data.text: It is good that you are have more (just in case yoh feeling hungry or meet someone interesting on the road to share with haha ) It is good to experiment with the food. If you want energy bar recipe that is easy to pack and eat while riding. Let me know. Good luck

data.text: Ingredients: 250g oats 100g (dry weight) white rice - cooked 200ml apple juice 200g frozen mixed berries 100g light brown sugar ( or honey or your favorit syrop) 1tbsp strawberry jam (or any jam you like) handful of raisins (or chopped dates) sprinkle of cinnamon

data.text: Have a good breakfast (oats and a banana and yoghurt. Take a banana and an energy bar, and lots of water. That‚Äôs enough! But you may want to buildup the distance over a few weeks as you‚Äôre clearly not used to it..

data.text: It‚Äôs probably too much, but bring it. Better to have too much than to bonk in the middle of nowhere. Next time you will have a better idea of what you need üòÑ
data.author: Tobias Christensen

data.text: Way too much IMHO. The bananas will probably turn to mush but try bringing two or three. Pre make a couple of sandwiches using whole wheat bread and put in baggies. Bigger issue is to have plenty of water and a refill source identified if possible. Also important are electrolytes (e.g., Nuun tablets or similar) to replace lost sodium, etc.. I use trail mix with nuts, cranberries and a little chocolate also. Seems to do the trick to keep me going. Chocolate chunks melt but oh well. Ps. Don‚Äôt do what I did on a 132 mile ride this past Monday which was to stop for a large milk shake. Took me 20 miles to recover‚Ä¶
data.author: John Goldman

data.text: excellent advice. I agree that a pre made sandwich is a good option. It also depends how hard you‚Äôre going, right? I find I can‚Äôt actually eat that much if I‚Äôm pushing. Fluid another story and I set a timer to remind me to drink regularly.
data.author: Henrietta Salnikov

data.text: it‚Äôs just a 50km ride! Electrolytes? Is in the the desert with high temperatures?
data.author: Michele Visser-Fitton

data.text: depends on temp, vertical, surface. I usually go prepared. Not so concerned if I know the ride will not be hard.
data.author: John Goldman

data.text: You need some jam!
data.author: Stephen Lerch

data.text: That seems to be a lot of white bread for any amount of exercise. üòï I do regular 50-80km rides with a bottle of water and a banana ( a cafe stop for coffee and a scone if I am lucky, just for fun not for nutritional need.) WHen I cycle toured in Vietnam ( so, high humudity and heat) I found a quick snack of dried fruit/nuts, plus an electrolyte drink, plus water, was all that I needed between breakfast and lunch breaks. I think that electrolyte drink was probably the most sustaining.
data.author: Biff Frederikson

data.text: 2 bananas and 2 PBJ's in baggies for 100km's in heat .
data.author: Stephen Castle

data.text: I do about 50 to 60 kms with one liter of water and two gels. High humidity, 28-30 Celsius, flat ground. Start off with three marshmallows or a couple of cookies.
data.author: Wai Sing Lee

data.text: Bit of an overkill for such a short ride. Maybe one banana and a decent drink.
data.author: John Nash Wainwright

data.text: That is a lot of food. Mostly carbs which is good as that is your primary energy source. Your body can only process about 30-60 grams of carb per hour, more than that and it sits in your stomach and could cause GI distress. 5 Bananas( each about 25 carbs) and bagels(about 45 carbs each) would be approx. 400 grams, so 80 grams an hour not including any honey. Personally I would make a couple sandwiches ahead and put in baggies, take 2-3 bananas. You may want to include a drink with electrolytes especially if you sweat much. You are not trying to replace the full mount of calories lost. Eat a high carb breakfast prior to ride and refuel within one hour after ride with carb and protein for best recovery.
data.author: Barbara Hart

data.text: Looks like you'll spend more time eating than riding...

I eat a lot during the day but don‚Äôt fuel especially for that ride. If your ride is 60km in 5h and it‚Äôs straight up a mountain‚Äî totally acceptable food quantity. If your ride is flat and you are going at a leisurely pace - I‚Äôd bring about 1/4 of that.

data.text: Fine for Africa, though most people you meet along the way usually want water
data.author: Caroline P Swain

data.text:
That looks like more than enough. If I was to add anything it would be proteins (2 boiled eggs), and calcium tablets (2). That is very carb rich, and I would not do that diet every day. For a fifty KM ride I would eat less than half that. You would probably burn about 1500 calories at the pace you are aiming for. https://caloriesburnedhq.com/calories-burned-biking/
Calories Burned Biking / Cycling Calculator
caloriesburnedhq.com
data.author: Mark Perry

data.text: For me it looks a lot too much, but I don't know how much you are used to eat/your body usual need. I didn't eat a lot during my long distance bicycle rides. I was happy in a couple of boiled eggs, up to two sandwiches and water. I avoid bananas on my rides, because they get mashed easily. For serious situations, which I never experienced, I had a little bag of mixed nuts with me.
data.author: Dorothee Hildebrandt

data.text: Make some energy balls/bars with nuts, figs etc. Google for receipes
data.author: Patricia Mc Cann

data.text: I'd take 1-2 bananas and 1 muffin or what that is for 50-60 KMs. And plenty of water
data.author: Serhiy Pazelskyy

data.text: Sorry, but I‚Äôm absolutely flummoxed by all this talk of electrolytes - unless you‚Äôre an athlete riding high speed in the mountains and long distances and I mean long distances in extreme conditions, electrolytes are over the top and unnecessary. Everyone is different and therefore needs are different. I assume you will not be remote and there will be food places on the way. Your not going to starve on a 5hr ride!
data.author: Michele Visser-Fitton

data.text: riding in 90+ degree weather in the desert you need electrolytes and lots of water.
data.author: Jan Long

data.text: I live in Vietnam, if I‚Äôm out for more than a couple of hours I definitely need electrolytes.
data.author: Sam Sharpe

data.text: Depends on the person. I cycled India without electrolytes and without a problem.
data.author: Michele Visser-Fitton

data.text: Yup! Bananas are high in potassium.

data.text: Seems like a lot of weight
